title: perfect solution
comment: - I was getting so tired of my phone's 1.5 GB internal memory limiting the number of apps I could install. Now that most apps as well as most of their runtime data is saved on a separate 6 GB ext4 partition on the SD card, that's one thing less to worry about. Currently running a custom Android 5.0 Cyanogenmod 12 on my Xperia L with ThunderZap 4.10 and full Gapps, and so far Mounts2SD works a lot smoother and more intuitive than Link2SD Plus. Thanks SpazeDog (Hoping that Mounts2SD isn't dead)

title: Meh. Didn't do what I needed.
comment: I tried it. My internal storage kept getting used up, regardless of what settings I made in this app. Three stars for an honest effort, though. This app didn't make my apps not use the internal storage, rather more like it only moved some of the app data. I still ran out of storage space for apps, data and caches. I wrote an init script to replace /system/etc/init.d/01mvdalvik, so the system never has to worry with regards to app/cache storage. I decided to completely remove the internal storage from the equation, with regards to apps, dalvik-cache, system, cache, app-data. I have a second partition on my SD card that completely replaces the internal storage, and I love it. My solution forced me to learn the internals of CM7.

title: Awesome, just awesome.
comment: After modding my HTC Droid Incredible and putting Kit-Kat on it, I needed a way to increase the pathetic 700MB of internal memory, especially if I am going to be using ART instead of Dalvik-Cache. This app works very well and now I have 6GB of "internal" space. This,  alongside zram and a swap partition, have breathed new life into my phone. The only problem that I have is that it isn't showing the remaining space of the external partition. Even though I formated this partition as ext3, it's showing yaffs2.

title: Great app
comment: This has to be one of the most extensive sd-ext scripts I have ever used, the only issue I find with some phones is that SQlite3 doesn't get installed properly to /system/xbin/ . If this happens to you use jrummy's busybox installer to install SQlite3 to /system/xbin/ . Overall besides having to use busybox installer as a workaround for storage space threshold this an amazing script, great job and many thanks to the developer for creating such an amazing sceptre service

title: Indispensable
comment: One word to describe it. My phone is 4 years old and without the script provided by this app, I might be able to install SwiftKey and one other app.   If you are getting an insufficient space warning from Play, and you still have space on /data and /sd-ext, the app is probably to large for download, install and replacement. Open the settings, select move data to SD option. Reboot. Install update. Change setting back to normal and reboot again.

title: Works perfectly
comment: I've tried several of these apps/scripts, including Link2sd, Int2ext and what not. This is the only one that actually works (without messing up your phone so badly you need to factory reset). I had to buy a new class 10 memory card, though, the old one was class 2 and so slow it took half a minute to open an app. Now I have everything, the apps, app data and dalvik cache moved to sdcard, and it doesn't feel any slower than when things were on the phone. This app made my phone usable! Thank you so much!
Samsung galaxy s3

I have an S3 my self, working fine. Could you grap a logcat from the crash? You can use one of the logcat apps to help you with this in an easy way. If you could mail that to me, I will have a better chance of fixing it.

title: Only one issue
comment: Works good but apps take forever to download now... :(

The only way this app/script can affect app downloads, is if you moved app data to sd-ext. In that case, it is not this app's fault that your sdcard is to slow. Buy a faster card or avoid storing app data on it.

title: Essential
comment: For my phone.. would be unusable without this. Thanks. using with cyanogenmod gingerbread.

title: Crash on start
comment: Reported crash several times in last few months but no bug fix. Edit2: Preferences.java:476 ArrayIndexOutOfBounds: length=3; index=3  Sending in few minutes. Hopefully we can fix this and this is not huge problem. Thanks for fast response. I sent you email
Google has a very bad Crash Reporting feature, meaning only about 1% actually get's reported. Could you instead grab a logcat using one of the logcat apps and then mail the output to me?

title: Epic
comment: This app is flawless.Noobs who don't know how to use it rate it bad. thanks for keeping it free.

title: Where's Reversed Mount?
comment: Why have you removed the Reversed Mount option? I believe it was an essential feature and I really need it. I'll give 5 stars when Reversed Mount is back. However, this app is great. Keep it up.

Reversed mount should never have been added in the first place. It was unstable and there is no need for it. It does nothing other than reversing the mount points, you can obtain the same result by just selecting different things to be moved. 5 stars or not, reversed mount will never be added back, it only provides problems.
It won't even start app on note2 n im rooted , it starts then force close wat 2 do
The new version should have this fixed

title: thank s
comment: Working great on pacman 4.3

title: well done
comment: moving internal storage content to another SD card is an essential function on some phones.  the internal storage space is simply not enough if you pin a lot of Play content for offline storage, download a lot of large apps, or whatever else.  Mounts2SD solves this problem in a more functional way than any similar apps i've tried.  unlike linking-based to-SD apps, Mounts2SD seems to work flawlessly with moving the content of any apps, including those that provide widgets.  most importantly for me, it works

title: Still cool
comment: Missing the option of changing external data into internal and vice versa. But love the new ui

This is not missing, it was removed as it proved to unstable. Also, it is not really needed. The only thing it does, is let you see the sd-ext partition from within the Android Settings, but you have the app for that. It can even display both partitions which Android Settings cannot.

title: Poor
comment: Can't find the reverse mount option anymore and the other options aren't compatible with CM9 or 10. If you want the old version go to SpazeDog's source forge site and download the 2.x apk  like I did so you can have a working version.

Reverse mount is removed. And this script and app is working fine on multiple CM7, 9, 10, 10.1 and 10.2 so if you have issues, it is not related to the app itself. If you visit XDA, there are plenty of people that can help, me included. Beats just submitting bad reviews on something that could be related to something else.

title: Upgrade Went Smoothly!
comment: v2.2 to v3.4.2 upgrade went smoothly. Not sure why my SD-EXT ext3 filesystem is no longer set to journal (I originally set it up to be journaling and this app seems to have overrided my intent). Also, Still can't control Storage Threshold - no matter what sqlite binary is used. Had to restore ROM to get original (was working for other apps) sqlite binary back. Setting not so important to me - and certainly not worth the hassle of restoring ROM just to undo DEV's fix. EVO 4G/MikG 3.1/Stock Kernel.

Journal settings can be set in the apps configure, check to see if it is set to enable it. About sqlite, could you mail a debug log (Can be created from the log tab). Maybe not the biggest issue for you, but if it could be fixed, then that would not be so bad :)

comment: Still use it despite of some problems. Thanks for the clarifications.

Boot animations is stalled when safe-mode is unchecked (Cannot do anything about that). Threshold is missing a working binary (ROM Issue). Ext4 DRIVER is NOT the same as Ext4 FileSystem. Often the Ext4 driver used for both 2, 3 and 4. Readahead is because you have another script that changes it. I cannot stop other scripts from doing this.

title: Good work!
comment: It still takes a long time to boot! Is there a way to fix it?  Other than that it works great on 4.3

Android 4.3 uses a new Daemon mode for it's superuser to bypass the SELinux security. RootFW used in Mounts2SD is not compatible with this in the current release. There is a whole new app with new libraries etc. on it's way which among other things, fixes this compatibility issue. You can try this new app already by going to the XDA Thread.
Nice

title: Good
comment: I love this

title: galaxy s 4
comment: doesn't open. after root check it force closes..

title: Great but reverse mount doesn't work on Galaxy Y
comment: A Great app. Much Much better than Link2sd and other ones. Would have given 5 stars if reverse mount would have worked. When I checked the option "reverse mount" and unchecked all other options options except "Status" and rebooted it got stuck at the boot screen showing Samsung logo. I kept it for nearly 1 hour but no change. Then I tried checking all options including "reverse mount" then also same thing happened. However everything else is working fine. My internal memory is now 154 mb free out of total 1

It has nothing to do with Galaxy Y. You are using a pure implementation of init.d, which is not the apps fault. Besides, rmount was removed in the new version because it is an unstable feature with the many pure implementations out there. Also it was not needed. There is no point in reversing the mount points.
Previous version was better!

If you could read code, you would not say that. Also, if you could be a bit more specific, then I would have a better chance of changing whatever you feel is wrong with this one. It's fine to criticize, but please remember to add some reasons for your opinions.

title: At last at last
comment: I am able to mount my sd-partition  :)  :) However there is one problem, sometimes after reboot the system fails totally and irreversibly , a factory reset only solves problem, I am still testing this trying to move the required apps like play services to sd FAT partition so that in case of a crash the system will only fail partially.   For those who are facing problems This might work 1-Backup data and then factory reset 2-First install - mounts2sd 3-open the app, , grant root access when asked, 4-Go to Application settings, install the script, re-run sqlite 3 fix just in case 5-check the relevant boxes in settings-the "data move", "cache move" etc, check the debug box, just in case anything goes wrong 6-Allocate 10% in "Storage threshold"   just to be safe, but may not be neede for some users 7-Move "mounts2sd" to memory card manually from android system settings (most important) then Reboot, 8-Mounts2SD should run automatically on next boot  9-Open the app and check the log for more info, and the storage use in "Android applications menu" should show very limited internal memory usage

title: Good App has limitations
comment: This is a great app. But the app has limitations. I have the LG Esteem ms910. This phone has issues with second partition it will only recognized FAT32 and only the last partition on an sdcard. Had to create three partitions a fat partition and 2 - fat32 partition. After Hours research I was able to fix the download 498 error. I'm still working on trying to organize how my sdcard is read. But other than that the application works. I believe this is not an issue with the application but with my phone. The LG Esteem cannot read ext2,3,4 partition, even with installed supported files. As stated had to create 3 FAT partitions (FAT=7.8MB, FAT32=384MB, FAT32=29.61GB). Mount2sd mounts the /sd-ext from my Internal 4GB memory and not my sdcard, it does not even see the (FAT or first FAT32 partitions and the third partition is read by my phone). It however did move my /cache to my Internal 4GB memory, which is what I needed to fix the download 498 error because my cache was always at 100% used. When connect via USB the PC reads the Internal 4GB and the External 29.61 GB. One drawn back when sdcard is inserted in memory reader on PC it only reads the second partition (384MB).

You need to create the sd-ext partition. This is a second partition on the sdcard which will be used as the second data partition

title: Just seem to screw up system
comment: Before installing this app I had 2 sdcard mounts. sdcard & sdcard2. I could move apps to the external sdcard2, but wanted to put apps onto sdcard instead. I'm still trying to sort the mess that mounts2sd made. I can now only put apps onto main storage. Uninstall of mounts2sd didn't remove the init.d script and I'm still trying to work out what else. If I can work out the other damage it does I'll write a repair script for others to use. This app shouldn't be in the app store.

Maybe you should just learn not to mess with things you don't understand. Or at least read up about it first. This app does not move anything to main partitions on the sdcard, or to the internal for that mater. No sd-ext script does. And there is a link to XDA with further help and a lot more details to guide you.

title: Dud - HTC Desire - Cyagenomod 7.2 - 4ext Recovery
comment: I spent days and days fiddling with both Mounts2SD and Link2SD to get either one of them to work on my phone. I spent hours cruising the xda developers forum, phandroid and other forums looking for solutions to my problems. With Mounts2sd, I tried every setting under the sun. Whether I ran it in safe mode or not, it just didn't work on my phone. That is not to say, of course, that it won't work on other phones as demonsrated by the many positive comments here. Link2SD is a bit pointless because it still leaves data in the phone memory, and you WILL eventually hit the dreaded "Phone Memory Low". DATA2SD, on the other hand, worked first time - and my HTC Desire is singing along with 1GB of internal memory. The whole exercise, however, was not pointless. I learnt more about Android than I thought I ever would. The most important thing to remember, is to BACKUP YOUR PHONE before you even start, and at every point along the way so that you can easily restore the last best setup - and start fiddling again.

title: Looks excellent, can't figure out how to config.
comment: I grabbed this app hoping that my days of tearing my hair out were finally opver, and it looks like they would have been, had I been able to get this app to work properly. However, after inputting the configuration I wanted, rebooting, only to find the config back to the way it started, and nothing changed, over, and over, and over, again, I've all but lost hope of ever finding a solution.  Unfortunately, documentation totally sucks, which is why this app gets a thumbs down from me. It can probably do what I need, but my total inability to get it to actually follow through on that promise cannot, at this point, be blamed purely on myself.

If you looked closer, you would have seen the message "Running in safe-mode" in the top of the app. A visit to the xda-developers.com thread mentioned in the app description, would have directed you to the option "Disable safe-mode" in the app, which in turn would have done what you wanted.
